courseDescription: Computer based drafting methods are taught with a major emphasis on 'Hands On' practice using 2-D AutoCAD software in the computer lab, along with the various methods of editing, manipulation, visualization and presentation of technical drawings.  This course includes the basic principles of engineering drawing/hand sketching, dimensioning and tolerancing.
Technical and Digital Skills: Hands on practice with 2-D AutoCAD software
Editing, manipulation, visualization and presentation of technical drawings
Basic principles of engineering drawing/hand sketching
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate technical drawings and specifications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to troubleshoot and resolve issues in AutoCAD software
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to manage and organize technical drawings

courseDescription: Application and characteristics, both physical and chemical, of the materials most commonly used in industry as well as procedures and processes used in converting raw materials into a finished product.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physical and chemical characteristics of industrial materials
Knowledge of manufacturing procedures and processes
Conversion of raw materials into finished products

courseDescription: A laboratory course dealing with the standard methods of inspecting and testing materials used in engineering applications with emphasis on laboratory reports, including presentation and interpretation of experimental data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Standard methods of inspecting engineering materials

courseDescription: The basic laws of thermodynamics, properties of fluids, heat, and work and their applications in processes and cycles and an introduction to conduction heat transfer.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of basic laws of thermodynamics
Understanding of heat and work applications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in heat and work applications

courseDescription: A fundamental treatment of coplanar and three-dimensional kinematics and kinetics of particles and rigid bodies, including relative motion, mass moment of inertia, Newton's laws, work and energy and impulse and momentum.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of coplanar and three-dimensional kinematics
Knowledge of kinetics of particles and rigid bodies
Understanding of mass moment of inertia
Comprehension of work, energy, impulse and momentum principles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to solve complex dynamical problems
Analytical skills to interpret and analyze physical phenomena
Problem-solving skills in various dynamical scenarios

courseDescription: Practical analyses of fundamental machine elements such as shafts, springs, and screws. Fundamental principles required for the correct design of the separate elements which compose the machine with attention given to problems of synthesis and the interrelationships of the design of elements within the sub-assembly. Topics include stress analysis of screws, belts, clutches, brakes, chains and thin and thick cylinders, and lubrication and bearings
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of fundamental machine elements such as shafts, springs, and screws
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding the interrelationships of the design of elements within the sub-assembly
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating design elements within a sub-assembly

courseDescription: The study of fluid statics and dynamics, including momentum, energy, Bernoulli's equation, laminar and turbulent fluid flow and friction in pipes, fluid machinery, and open-channel flow.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of fluid statics and dynamics
Knowledge of laminar and turbulent fluid flow
Skills in handling friction in pipes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing momentum and energy in fluid mechanics
Solving problems related to fluid flow and friction
Ability to apply theoretical knowledge to practical situations

courseDescription: A laboratory course dealing with the verification of fluid equations and principles and the characteristics of fluid machinery with emphasis on presentation and interpretation of experimental data.
A study of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer and heat exchangers. Emphasis is on applications and problem solving using current techniques, and modern correlations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and applying heat transfer principles

courseDescription: A study of the applications of thermodynamics.  Topics include the basic steam and gas turbine power cycles, internal combustion engines, introduction to refrigeration systems, gas mixtures, and psychrometrics applied to air conditioning processes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of steam and gas turbine power cycles
Knowledge of psychrometrics applied to air conditioning processes

courseDescription: Experiments dealing with applied thermodynamics, mechanical power and energy systems with emphasis on laboratory report writing, including presentation and interpretation of experimental data.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a technical team in a lab setting

Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the Career Development Services program prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.  (offered fall, spring, summer)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with department and Career Development Services
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment and evaluation of work experience relevance
Identification and application of academic relevance in work experience

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired. Allows students to gain short duration career-related experience.
Available for pass/fail grading only.
Study of selected topics.

A study of the integrated modeling and optimal design of a physical system, which includes sensors, actuators, electronic components, and its embedded digital control system.  Includes simultaneous optimal design practice with respect to the realization of the design specifications related to different engineering domains.

Technical and Digital Skills: Design of screws, belts, clutches, brakes, chains, thin and thick cylinders
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Attention to detail in subsystem assemblies

courseTitle: Modeling and Simulation of Mechatronic Systems
courseDescription: The course provides foundations, principles, methods, and tools for modeling and simulation of electro-mechanical components and systems using appropriate modeling techniques. The course is focused on the multi-body dynamics systems, fluid, hydraulic, and electrical systems.

A study of the application of thermodynamics to power plants, engines, compressors, turbines, and associated systems. A detailed study is made of fossil fuel power plants with an introductory study of nuclear power and other energy conversion systems.

The design and application of refrigeration and air conditioning systems.  Studies are made of compressors, condensers, evaporators, psychometric processes, load calculations and air distribution systems.  High performance vapor compression systems, absorption systems and other cycles are analyzed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing refrigeration and air conditioning systems
Understanding of high performance vapor compression systems
Knowledge of absorption systems and other cycles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of refrigeration and air conditioning systems
Analyzing high performance vapor compression systems
Analyzing absorption systems and other cycles

courseDescription: Reactor physics principles as applied to the design and operation of various types of commercial nuclear power reactors. Topics include sources of radiation and interaction with matter, neutron interactions, diffusion theory, and reactor kinetics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing various types of commercial nuclear power reactors
Knowledge of radiation sources and interaction with matter
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying reactor physics principles to solve problems
Interpreting interactions of radiation and matter
Applying diffusion theory for problem solving

courseDescription: Complete study of the nuclear fuel cycle, from mining through fabrication, fuel management in an operating commercial power reactor, spent fuel management, and fuel reprocessing, with emphasis on chemical engineering considerations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the nuclear fuel cycle
Knowledge in mining and fabrication processes
Management of fuel in an operating commercial power reactor

courseDescription: This course includes: fundamental principles of naval architecture including nomenclature, geometry, stability, hydrostatics, structures, and motions; ship design processes; and a basic introduction to shipboard systems such as HVAC, refrigeration, power generation, propulsion, hydraulics, electronics, cargo handling systems, seawater systems, freshwater systems, and fuel, lube and other oil systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of fuel, lube and other oil systems

courseDescription: This course builds upon MET 475 and provides a more in-depth look on how the marine shipbuilding industry is using various software including SIEMENS PLM, 3D CAD modeling and new technologies like laser scanners and augmented reality to reshape the future of shipbuilding, maintenance, and repair processes. Focus will be based on model-based learning and creating a 'digital thread' of information. Students will practice what they learn on shipbuilding concepts using commercial software that is widely used across automotive, aerospace, and marine industries.
Technical and Digital Skills: Creating a digital thread of information
Practicing shipbuilding concepts using commercial software
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating and applying new technologies in shipbuilding
Understanding and applying software used in automotive, aerospace, and marine industries

courseDescription: A study of the fundamental principles and performance characteristics of spark ignition and diesel internal combustion engines.  Overview of engine types and their operation, engine design and operating parameters; ideal and semi-empirical models of engine cycles; combustion, fluid flow and thermal considerations in engine design and performance.  Laboratory evaluation of engine performance using flow and dynamometer systems. (cross-listed with MAE 477/MAE 577)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of spark ignition and diesel internal combustion engines
Knowledge of various engine types and their operation
Understanding of engine design and operating parameters
Understanding of ideal and semi-empirical models of engine cycles
Understanding of combustion, fluid flow and thermal considerations in engine design and performance
Ability to use flow and dynamometer systems for engine performance evaluation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of engine performance using laboratory tools

courseDescription: This course looks at maintenance systems: predictive, preventative and corrective; large scale maintenance systems, principles of reliability engineering, maritime logistics; planning for maintenance and repair, using and ordering spare parts, technical manuals, system specifications, and shipyard operations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of maintenance systems: predictive, preventative and corrective
Knowledge of large scale maintenance systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication for ordering spare parts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Planning and executing maintenance and repair
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing maintenance and repair
